newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft files for bigger preferred offer.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft files for bigger preferred offer.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. on Tuesday increased the size of its planned offering of preferred shares to $1.0 billion, from $862.5 million, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
In an amended filing, the software company said it was adding $137.5 million to the original amount it filed to register on Dec. 2.

The $1 billion offering includes "just under 15 percent" as an over-allotment option available to underwriters, said Robert Eshelman, a Microsoft lawyer at the company's headquarters in Redmond, Wash.
Underwriters Goldman, Sachs & Co. and Morgan Stanley & Co. may exercise the option to cover any increase in demand for the shares. All other terms of the offering are unchanged, Eshelman said.
The preferred shares are principal-protected, in that investors will be able to get back their principal in cash or common stock at the end of three years along with quarterly dividends.
